content: The Act may be cited as the "Diesel Emissions Reduction Act of 2010" and establishes the Diesel Emissions Reduction Program. Changes include adjustments to national grant, rebate, and loan programs, with specific requirements for eligible entities to apply for competitive loans. Amendments to the Energy Policy Act of 2005 include adding provisions for contract programs, allowing the Administrator to use contracting authority for diesel vehicles owned by private entities under Federal contracts. The Administrator can enter contracts with eligible contractors to administer programs for providing rebates or loans for diesel vehicles or equipment upgrades. Eligible contractors must have the capacity to sell vehicles, arrange financing, or upgrade vehicles with certified engines or technologies. Public notification must be made within 60 days. The Administrator must publish details of grants, rebates, and loans awarded within 60 days on the EPA website. This includes the number and amount of rebates or loans for diesel vehicles, breakdown of funded technologies, and descriptions of applications for other rebates and loans. States like Guam, the United States Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands collectively receive an allocation equal to 1/53 of the funds available for distribution to States. If any of these states do not qualify, funds are reallocated accordingly. In case a State does not qualify for an allocation, funds will be reallocated to qualified States based on population proportions. Rebates are included in state programs as per the Energy Policy Act of 2005 amendments. In paragraph (2), grants will now include rebates. Paragraph (3) states that grants, rebates, or loans provided under this section must be used. Priority in providing grants, rebates, and loans should follow the priorities in section 792(c)(4). States must publicly notify within 60 days of awarding a grant, rebate, or loan on their website. The amendment includes adding rebates to grants in the evaluation and reporting of funds provided under the Energy Policy Act of 2005. Additionally, the authorization of appropriations section is amended to reflect the changes. Authorization of appropriations is set at $200,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2012 through 2016, with 1 percent allocated for management and oversight by the Administrator.
